Introduction

Lice infestation, or pediculosis, is a condition in which parasitic insects feed on human blood.  There are 3 types of lice that infest humans: head lice (Pediculus humanus capitis), body lice (Pediculus humanus humanus), and pubic lice (Pthirus pubis).

Pathophysiology and risk factors

Lice are translucent ectoparasites (

image 1
) that depend on human blood for survival.  They have "crab-like" claws (
image 2
) that help them attach to human hair and specialized mouthparts that pierce human skin.  Lice infestation occurs when adult female lice lay eggs, known as nits (
image 3
), on either hair shafts (head and pubic lice) or clothing and bedding (body lice).  The nits remain firmly attached until they hatch into nymphs in about a week.  Nymphs mature into adult lice and live for about a month, feeding on human blood daily.  Without a host, lice die in 2-3 days.

  • Head and pubic lice are transmitted through direct contact.  Lice do not jump, fly, or have nonhuman hosts.  Pubic lice are not transmitted through genital secretions; therefore, condoms are not effective prophylaxis for pubic lice.  Transmission through shared fomites (eg, hairbrushes, towels) can also occur but is less common.
  • Body lice live on clothing and visit the host's skin only to feed.  Therefore, body lice transmission most commonly occurs through shared contact with fomites (eg, clothing, bedding).

Lice infestation occurs worldwide, most commonly in children.  Risk factors that may increase the risk for lice infestation include:

  • Close contact with an individual with lice infestation (eg, in schools/daycares, among sports teams)
  • Poor personal hygiene or living in crowded/unsanitary conditions (particularly for body lice)

Clinical presentation

The clinical presentation of lice infestation varies depending on the type of lice and the affected area.  Common signs and symptoms include:

  • Pruritus, erythema, excoriation, and lichenification, especially around the scalp, neck, and shoulders (head lice); pubic and perianal areas (pubic lice); or trunk (body lice).  Pruritus occurs due to an allergic reaction to lice saliva.  Patients typically do not develop pruritus until sensitization occurs, up to 6 weeks after infestation.
  • Visible nits or adult lice can be found on the hair or clothing.
  • Blue-gray macules may be present on the trunk and extremities due to anticoagulant effects of lice saliva.

Excess scratching can lead to secondary bacterial infections, such as impetigo.  In addition, body lice can serve as vectors for zoonotic infectious diseases (eg, Rickettsia prowazekii [epidemic typhus], Bartonella quintana [trench fever]).

Diagnosis

Visualization of lice or nits (

image 4
) on the hair shaft or clothing (
image 5
) confirms the diagnosis.  A magnifying glass or handheld light may be used to aid in the identification of lice and nits.  In addition, wet combing (using a fine-tooth comb to systematically brush wet hair) can aid in visualization of head lice.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging studies are not typically indicated.

Differential diagnosis

The differential diagnosis of lice infestation includes other conditions that cause pruritus:

  • Scabies:  a skin infestation caused by the Sarcoptes scabiei mite and typically presents with intense pruritus, especially at night, and erythematous papules with linear burrows (
    image 6
    ) at the site of infestation.  Unlike lice infestations, scabies infestations typically occur in interdigital spaces and flexural areas.
  • Seborrheic dermatitis:  a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by erythema, scaling, and pruritus, particularly in areas rich in sebaceous glands (eg, scalp, face, trunk).  It often presents with greasy, yellow scales (
    image 7
    ) and may be associated with dandruff.  Unlike nits, which are firmly attached to the hair shafts, dandruff is easily removed.
  • Tinea capitis:  an infection caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton tonsurans that presents as a scaly, pruritic, erythematous patch of hair loss (
    image 8
    ).  Small black dots representing broken hair shafts are typical.

Management

First-line treatment of head and pubic lice includes topical pediculicides (eg, permethrin, ivermectin) on the affected area.  Most pediculicides are neurotoxins (eg, permethrin blocks parasite sodium ion conduction in nerve cell membrane channels) that cause louse paralysis and death.  Treatment should be repeated after 7-10 days to ensure the eradication of newly hatched lice.

Manual lice removal via wet combing is an alternate treatment for patients with head lice for whom standard pediculicides are not feasible (eg, young infants, resource-limited populations).  This must be repeated a few times weekly for several weeks to fully eradicate the infestation.

Prior to treatment, the presence of live lice should be confirmed.  Nits far from the skin surface likely represent old egg casings that have already hatched and generally do not require treatment.

Because body lice live on clothing (not hair), the primary method of eradication involves laundering recently used clothing, bedding, and personal items in hot water (>54 C [130 F]).  Items that cannot be washed should be isolated from any potential host for 2 weeks.  This practice is also reasonable for items recently used by patients with head and pubic lice.

Patients should be advised to avoid direct contact of the affected area with others while undergoing treatment.  Children with head lice may continue to go to school but should avoid direct head-to-head contact.

Prognosis

With appropriate treatment and preventive measures, the prognosis for lice infestation is excellent.  Most cases can be successfully treated, and complications are uncommon.  However, reinfestation can occur if preventive measures are not followed or if there is continued exposure to infested individuals.

Summary

Lice infestation, or pediculosis, is a condition in which parasitic insects feed on human blood.  Lice infestation occurs worldwide, and patients present with pruritus and skin irritation.  Treatment involves eradication with pediculicides while avoiding reexposure.
